title: Survivor of rare rapid-ageing disease progeria dies at 28
description: Sammy Basso, the longest living survivor of progeria, has died at 28. Progeria causes rapid aging and has a life expectancy of 13.5 years. Basso, diagnosed at two, co-founded the Italian Progeria Association and was featured in a National Geographic documentary. There are 130 recognized cases worldwide.

title: ICMR to study efficacy of Metformin, Inositol in PCOS treatment
description: ICMR will study the efficacy of Metformin and Inositol in improving fertility and birth outcomes in Indian women with PCOS. The multi-centre trial aims to fill the knowledge gap regarding these drugs' effectiveness in the Indian context, focusing on outcomes like pregnancy conception, menstrual cycle regularisation, and endocrinological improvements.

title: Should you need to worry about the asteroids hitting Earth? Understanding real challenges of asteroids grabbing attention
description: An asteroid, 2024 ON, comparable in size to the Eiffel Tower, recently captured media attention but posed no actual threat to Earth. Despite challenges in tracking Near Earth Objects (NEOs), NASA’s DART mission demonstrated a successful asteroid diversion strategy. The upcoming Hera mission aims to further refine these defense techniques.

title: PM Modi to launch Unified Genomic Chip and indigenous sex-sorted semen production tech to boost dairy farming
description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi is set to launch the Unified Genomic Chip and indigenous sex-sorted semen production technology in Maharashtra to assist farmers in identifying high-quality cattle and producing more female calves at lower costs. Additionally, he will release the 18th instalment of Rs 20,000 crore under the PM-Kisan scheme to benefit 9.4 crore farmers.

title: Antarctica turning green 'dramatically', trend accelerated over years, study finds
description: Antarctica's vegetation cover has grown significantly, increasing from less than a square kilometre to nearly 12 square kilometres between 1986 and 2021. The accelerated greening, driven by climate change and reduced sea-ice extent, highlights the rapid and concerning transformation of the Antarctic Peninsula's landscape, emphasizing the urgent need for further research and action to protect this vulnerable region.

title: 10-m high moon replica to be erected in Guwahati to celebrate success of Chandrayaan mission
description: Guwahati will host the India International Science Festival from November 30, featuring a 10-meter high moon replica by artist Luke Jerram to celebrate the Chandrayaan mission. Organized by the Ministry of Science and Technology, this event aims to promote science achievements and discuss India's development by 2047. It includes sessions on north-east development, nuclear energy, and biotechnology's role in economic growth.

title: Seek science milestones, not personal glory: Gaganyaan astronaut; next batch selection soon: Isro Chief
description: Group Captain Angad Pratap talks about the evolving diversity in India’s human spaceflight programme, emphasizing science over personal glory. ISRO seeks candidates with expertise in experimental domains and aerospace research. The Gaganyaan training is comprehensive, covering academics, physical fitness, and survival skills, preparing astronauts for future space missions.

title: Study finds how new imaging method accurately detects kidney cancer
description: A recent study conducted by UCLA Health Jonsson Comprehensive Cancer Center researchers found that new, non-invasive imaging technology can detect clear-cell renal cell carcinoma, the most common kind of kidney cancer.

title: LNG's 20-year greenhouse gas footprint found to be 30% more than coal's: Study
description: LNG leaves a greenhouse gas footprint significantly higher than coal over a 20-year period, according to a new study. This footprint, driven primarily by methane emissions during extraction and liquefaction, remains equal to or worse than coal even over 100 years, challenging its label as a cleaner energy source.

title: Students from Jaffna and TN space startup collaborate to develop communication satellite
description: Students from a Sri Lankan university and SpaceKidz India are collaborating to develop a communication satellite, set to launch by ISRO in late 2025. The project aims to equip students from Jaffna and Tamil Nadu with skills in satellite technology, offering groundbreaking research opportunities and STEM education.

title: NASA to hold press conference featuring astronaut Tracy Dyson
description: NASA astronaut Tracy C. Dyson will discuss her six-month mission aboard the International Space Station on Oct. 4. Her mission highlights include remotely controlling a robot, using a 3D bioprinter for cardiac tissue, and conducting protein crystallization experiments. The event at NASA’s Johnson Space Center will be streamed live on NASA’s platforms.

title: Nasa switches off instrument on Voyager 2 spacecraft to save power
description: NASA has turned off Voyager 2's plasma science instrument to conserve power, enabling the spacecraft to continue its mission until the 2030s. Launched in 1977, Voyager 2 is over 12 billion miles from Earth and explores beyond the sun's bubble. Meanwhile, Voyager 1 continues its journey in interstellar space, over 15 billion miles from Earth.

title: Solar eclipse to create rare 'ring of fire' over South America
description: An annular solar eclipse will create a rare "ring of fire" phenomenon visible in parts of South America on Wednesday. A "ring of fire" occurs when the Moon lines up between the Sun and the Earth to create a solar eclipse, but does not block out the Sun's light entirely, Diego Hernandez with the Buenos Aires Planetarium told AFP. On Wednesday, the Moon "will be a little farther from the Earth than usual, which happens about once a month," he said, meaning it will not be able to completely cover the Sun.

title: Genetic study tracks migration history of elephants in India, finds 'dilution of diversity'
description: A genetic study reveals Indian elephants' migration from north to south over 1,00,000 years, highlighting bottlenecks that decreased genetic diversity. Researchers found five genetically distinct populations, with northern elephants being more diverse than the southern. This information aids conservation strategies for the endangered species, which constitute 60% of the global Asian elephant population.

title: Is Mount Everest, the Earth's tallest mountain still growing? What we know
description: Mount Everest's increasing height is attributed to the isostatic rebound caused by the merger of the Kosi and Arun rivers about 89,000 years ago. According to their estimates, isostatic rebound is responsible for approximately 10% of the yearly uplift rate of Everest. Isostatic rebound is a geological phenomenon that is not limited to the Himalayan region.

title: World's oldest cheese found on mummies? Scientists uncover 3,600-year-old mystery
description: Scientists have identified the oldest known cheese from the remains of Bronze Age mummies in China's Tarim Basin, dating back to around 2,000 BC. Known as kefir cheese, it was found on the heads and necks of Xiaohe people mummies. Analysis revealed it contained genetic material from cows and goats, highlighting ancient dairy practices.

title: “I hacked Nasa": Here’s why the space agency honoured a hacker’s contribution
description: An independent hacker has exposed a second breach of NASA's systems, highlighting critical vulnerabilities. After reporting the issues, NASA acknowledged the hacker’s contributions and issued an appreciation letter for responsibly identifying and helping to fix the flaws. The online community praised the hacker’s integrity and NASA's approach to rewarding security researchers.

title: Nasa astronauts receive new ride home as SpaceX Dragon capsule arrives at ISS
description: Two astronauts stuck on the ISS since June finally got their return transport through a SpaceX capsule after NASA deemed Boeing's Starliner unsafe due to thruster failures and helium leaks. The Dragon capsule will remain docked until February, while NASA continues inspecting the Starliner.

title: Earth gets a ‘mini moon’ for 2 months and it has a Mahabharata connection
description: Asteroid '2024 PT5', discovered by ATLAS in August, flew past Earth on September 29 and will orbit it for 57 days. This mini-moon, part of the Arjuna asteroid group, is closely monitored by ISRO's NETRA. It will leave Earth's orbit on November 25 and is expected to return in 2055.

title: Physical activity and beating stress are important to reduce heart diseases: Dr Raghava Sarma
description: Dr PV Raghava Sarma of Lalitha super specialty hospital highlights the urgent need for physical activity and stress management to reduce heart diseases in India. The hospital has initiated awareness activities for World Heart Day, including free screenings. He recommends a balanced diet, regular exercise, and avoiding smoking and alcohol to improve heart health.

title: Life of Indian astronaut: Gaganyaatri Angad Pratap tells about psychological, flight and survival training

title: NASA to track temporary ‘mini moon’ asteroid with planetary radar — All you need to know
description: Last month, Earth acquired a temporary mini moon, 2024 PT5, detected by astronomers. NASA will monitor its path, as it orbits for nearly two months before departing in late November, with a potential return in 2055.

title: October 2024: List of celestial events to watch this month

title: Climate change impact: Antarctica is fast turning green due to extreme heat waves; here’s why it’s not a good thing
description: Antarctica's icy landscapes are turning green due to extreme heat, with vegetation increasing over tenfold in 40 years. Researchers warn this change, particularly in the Antarctic Peninsula, may harm local wildlife and alter the region's climate dynamics.

title: WHO approves first monkeypox diagnostic test for emergency use. All you need to know about EUL procedure
description: The WHO has listed the Alinity m MPXV assay for mpox testing under its Emergency Use Listing, enhancing global diagnostic capacity amid rising outbreaks. This real-time PCR test allows for quick detection of the monkeypox virus from skin lesion swabs, aiming to improve timely treatment and control.

description: NASA's Europa Clipper spacecraft is set to launch on October 10, 2024, to study Jupiter's moon Europa, where evidence suggests potential life-sustaining ingredients exist. The mission aims to assess the moon's ocean beneath its icy crust over six years and includes 49 flybys.

title: Mission to 'rescue' Sunita Williams, Butch Wilmore: NASA set to stream live launch of SpaceX Crew-9 — How to watch
description: NASA astronaut Nick Hague and Roscosmos cosmonaut Aleksandr Gorbunov will launch to the International Space Station on September 28. The SpaceX Crew-9 mission launches at 1:17 pm EDT from Cape Canaveral, with live coverage starting at 9:00 am the same day.

title: ‘Sign of exciting discoveries...?’: NASA's Perseverance rover spots ‘Zebra Rock’ on Mars
description: Perseverance rover's discovery of a distinctive striped rock called 'Freya Castle' on Mars has captivated scientists and the public. The rock's unusual features indicate it may originate from a different location, fueling anticipation for future geological discoveries in the region.

title: Sahara Desert sees a surprising burst of greenery, NASA shares stunning images | Watch
description: Some regions in Morocco, Algeria, Tunisia, and Libya—which barely receive a few inches of rain per year—now show traces of green after an extratropical cyclone drenched parts of northwestern Sahara on September 7 and 8. The cyclone drenched large, treeless swaths of the region.

title: ‘Strong evidence’: Breast cancer linked in food packaging; scientists raise alarm
description: A study reveals nearly 200 chemicals linked to breast cancer in food packaging and plastic tableware. Researchers urge removing these harmful substances to protect health, as 76 have been found in people. Experts call for stricter regulations and suggest alternatives to reduce exposure.

title: NASA, SpaceX delay Crew-9 mission tasked to bring back Sunita Williams – Here's why
description: NASA-SpaceX Crew 9 mission has now been scheduled for “instantaneous launch” on Saturday, September 28. There's also a backup opportunity available on Sunday.

title: Spiral galaxy 59 million light-years away looks like this: NASA shares stunning video of 'young, hot stars'
description: NASA's Hubble Space Telescope shared a stunning video of the spiral galaxy located 59 million light-years from Earth, showcasing bright blue patches indicating young stars and starburst regions where star formation is accelerated.

title: In charts: Can alternative proteins be the food of the future?
description: India’s government has come up with a new policy that will promote smart proteins that can help the country in its net-zero journey. What are smart proteins, and can India find a way to rule the global market?

title: Mpox: Kerala plans revised guidelines after India's first case of Clade 1b strain
description: The Pinarayi Vijayan government in Kerala said it will release revised guidelines for the prevention and treatment of Mpox after the state reported the first confirmed case of the new strain Clade 1b in the country on Monday

title: Chandrayaan-3 update: Pragyan rover spots 160-km-wide crater on Moon's South Pole, ‘probably formed before…’
description: India's Chandrayaan-3 mission identified a 160-km-wide crater near its landing site on the Moon's South Pole, revealing vital details about lunar geological history. The crater discovered by the Pragyan rover is located near the Aitken basin.

title: 6 NASA images of Arp 107: Why are those mysterious ‘galactic eyes’ looking at you from space?
description: The US Space Agency shared stunning images of Arp 107, a pair of colliding galaxies. Captured by the Spitzer Space Telescope, these visuals illustrate star formation and feature a supermassive black hole, emphasizing the captivating nature of interacting galaxies in space.

title: Multiple asteroids may have contributed to dinosaur extinction, scientists reveal
description: New research points to a second asteroid impact possibly contributing to the extinction of dinosaurs, challenging the long-held belief of a single impact event. This discovery comes as the European Space Agency (ESA) readies its Hera spacecraft for launch to study the results of NASA's asteroid redirection experiment from 2022. These missions aim to enhance our understanding of asteroid impacts and strengthen future planetary defense strategies in case of potential threats.

title: Is India at risk? NASA predicts strongest solar storm in seven years will hit Earth; Here’s what you should know!
description: A significant solar storm is on its way to Earth, raising alarms about potential disruptions to electronic communications and satellite operations. Dr. Annapurni Subramanian from the Indian Institute of Astrophysics, along with ISRO, is closely monitoring the situation to mitigate risks. With solar flares affecting technology, understanding the implications is crucial for both India and global systems.

title: How an 8-day trip turned into an 8-month nightmare for NASA astronauts Sunita Williams and Butch Wilmore
description: NASA astronauts Sunita Williams and Butch Wilmore, initially on an eight-day mission, were stranded on the ISS for eight months due to technical issues with the Boeing Starliner. Their rescue arrived aboard a SpaceX Dragon capsule, bringing an end to their extended stay.

title: European Space Agency to send spacecraft past Mars for 'crime scene investigation'
description: The European Space Agency's Hera spacecraft is set to investigate the aftermath of NASA’s DART mission, which successfully deflected the asteroid Dimorphos. Scheduled to launch soon, Hera will analyse the impact damage and gather crucial data to better understand asteroid threats and potential planetary defences.

title: NASA is flying to Jupiter next week to find alien life hidden inside its deep oceans
description: NASA is set to launch its Europa Clipper mission on October 10, 2024, aboard a SpaceX rocket from Kennedy Space Center. This ambitious mission aims to explore Europa, Jupiter’s icy moon, which may harbor a vast ocean beneath its surface. Through nearly 50 flybys, the spacecraft will gather crucial data to assess whether Europa can support life, marking a significant step in the search for extraterrestrial life.

title: Why is NASA turning off Voyager 2’s instruments in deep space, 12 billion miles from home?
description: NASA has turned off a critical instrument on Voyager 2 to save power. This will help extend the spacecraft's mission into the 2030s. Voyager 2, launched in 1977, is now exploring interstellar space with its twin, Voyager 1. Both spacecraft continue to provide valuable scientific data.

title: NASA Asteroid Alert: Two asteroids to fly by earth today – Here's what we know
description: NASA is monitoring two asteroids, one the size of an airplane and the other like a bus, flying by Earth today. Additionally, Earth has temporarily captured a second 'moon,' a 10-meter-wide asteroid named 2024 PT5, which will orbit for 57 days.

title: Scientists discover 40 mysterious craters beneath Lake Michigan. Here's what we know so far
description: Scientists found large craters in Lake Michigan using sonar technology. The discovery was made during a mission to map the lakebed. Researchers are now focused on understanding the role these craters play in the lake’s ecosystem. They plan to explore further to learn more about their formation and significance.

title: Chandrayaan-4 to bring back 2-3 kg moon samples
description: India's Chandrayaan-4 mission, set for 2029 and costing ₹2,104.06 crore, plans to return lunar surface samples. The mission will utilize five modules launched on two LVM3 vehicles. Key technologies, developed domestically, aim to advance skill development, create jobs, and drive technological progress.

title: Chandrayaan-3 landed within a buried, one of the oldest craters on Moon: PRL-ISRO study
description: Chandrayaan-3's Pragyan rover and Vikram lander have landed in an ancient, buried impact crater approximately 160 km in diameter and 4.4 km deep, near the south pole of the Moon. This location holds significant geological history, including materials from the South Pole Atkin basin.

title: Scientists found a massive underground ocean hidden 700km below Earth's surface. Here's all about it
description: Scientists have unearthed a massive underground ocean located 700 kilometers beneath Earth’s surface, found within ringwoodite’s crystalline structure. This hidden ocean, thrice the size of our surface oceans, may revolutionize our comprehension of Earth’s water cycle. Researchers used seismic data from earthquakes to identify these water-rich rocks, with further studies planned to understand its global impact.

title: Is Mount Everest still rising? The surprising truth behind its growth
description: Mount Everest continues to grow in height due to isostatic rebound, a process linked to the merger of the Kosi and Arun rivers about 89,000 years ago. This merger caused significant erosion, reducing land weight and increasing the mountain's elevation by an estimated 49-164 feet.

title: SpaceX capsule docks at ISS: NASA's Sunita Williams, Butch Wilmore set for 2025 return
description: A SpaceX capsule has docked at the ISS to bring back NASA astronauts Sunita Williams and Butch Wilmore, stranded due to Boeing Starliner issues. They are set to return in 2024 aboard SpaceX’s Crew-9 mission.

title: SpaceX Crew Dragon space capsule docks at ISS to rescue astronaut Sunita Williams, Butch Wilmore
Why Elon Musk's plan to colonize Mars may be a bad idea: Humans can turn green and go blind on the red planet
description: Colonizing Mars presents significant challenges, according to experts. Dr. Scott Solomon warns that the planet's harsh conditions could lead to mutations in children born there, including changes in skin color, weakened bones, and impaired eyesight. NASA plans to send humans to Mars by the 2030s, while SpaceX envisions a city on the planet within 30 years. Addressing these issues is crucial for the future of human settlement on Mars.

title: NASA hacker strikes again, exposes major security flaw; Here's how the space agency responded
description: Nasa Website Hacked: A hacker has claimed to have infiltrated NASA's systems, exposing security vulnerabilities. The hacker reported these issues to NASA, which acknowledged the effort with an official letter of appreciation. This incident highlights the importance of ethical hackers in securing sensitive systems and has sparked discussions on social media about their role.

title: How staying home during Covid lockdown cooled down the Moon's temperature by around -250 degrees, says new study
description: Moon Temperature: Indian researchers have discovered a link between the global Covid-19 lockdowns of 2020 and a decrease in the Moon's night-time surface temperatures. Using data from NASA's Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter, they found an 8-10 Kelvin drop in moon temperatures, attributed to reduced Earth's outgoing radiation during the lockdown period.

title: Stuck NASA astronauts Sunita Williams and Butch Wilmore welcome SpaceX capsule that'll bring them home next year
description: Two astronauts at the International Space Station since June received a new ride home with the arrival of a SpaceX capsule. NASA switched Butch Wilmore and Sunita Williams to SpaceX due to safety concerns with their Boeing Starliner capsule. The Dragon capsule will stay until February, extending their mission to over eight months.

title: Earth getting a mini-moon tonight. Here's how you can see it
description: Earth will gain a temporary mini-moon tonight as asteroid 2024 PT5, about 33 feet wide, orbits the planet until November 25. Discovered by NASA's Atlas on August 7, it will not be visible to the naked eye but can be captured by professional telescopes. The asteroid is expected to return in 2055.

title: Earth's second mini-moon 2024 PT5 to be visible from today: Here's what you need to know about it
description: Earth will briefly host a new visitor, asteroid 2024 PT5, from September 29 to November 25. Originating from the Arjuna asteroid belt, this mini-moon was detected by NASA in August. Although it won't be visible to the naked eye, professional telescopes will capture images of its journey past the stars.

title: Chandrayaan-3 landed on a 3.85 bn-year-old lunar crater, says researcher
description: India's Chandrayaan-3 mission has possibly landed in one of the Moon's oldest craters, dating back 3.85 billion years. Images from the Pragyan rover and satellites reveal unique geological features at the landing site, offering insights into the Moon's evolution. The site, named Shiv Shakti Point, contains material from various lunar regions.

title: NASA SpaceX Crew-9 soars: Nick, Aleksandr, and a furry co-pilot take off to bring Sunita Williams, Butch Wilmore back
description: NASA’s SpaceX Crew-9 mission successfully launched from Cape Canaveral, marking the first human spaceflight from pad 40. The crew, including NASA astronaut Nick Hague and Roscosmos cosmonaut Aleksandr Gorbunov, is en route to the ISS with a Zero-G indicator named Aurora. They are expected to dock on Sunday evening.

title: SpaceX launches rescue mission for stranded NASA astronauts Sunita Williams and Butch Wilmore
description: SpaceX launched a mission to rescue two astronauts stranded at the International Space Station. The capsule will bring them back in February after their Boeing spacecraft returned empty due to safety concerns. NASA's Nick Hague and Russia's Alexander Gorbunov are leading the mission, which highlights ongoing challenges in space travel.

title: Australian scientist confirm 100-year-old theory, discover  new cell type that can heal chronic injuries
description: Scientists from SAHMRI and the University of Adelaide have discovered a new cell type called EndoMac progenitors. These cells, found in the aortas of adult mice, can transform into blood vessel and immune cells. This discovery could lead to new treatments for chronic conditions like diabetes by improving healing processes.

title: NASA SpaceX Crew-9 launch details: When, where to watch live stream as Sunita Williams, Butch Wilmore make their way to Earth
description: Nasa will launch the SpaceX Crew-9 mission on Saturday, bringing astronauts Sunita Williams and Butch Wilmore back to Earth after their extended stay on the ISS. The mission includes Nasa astronaut Nick Hague and Roscosmos cosmonaut Aleksandr Gorbunov. Originally delayed due to Hurricane Helene, the launch is now set for September 28.

title: Orionid meteor shower from Halley's Comet starts: Here is how, where, and when to watch the annual cosmic event
description: The Orionids meteor shower, caused by debris from Halley's Comet, begins on September 26 and runs through November 22. The peak night is expected between October 20 and October 21. Observers are advised to find dark skies away from urban light pollution for the best viewing experience.

title: Scientists discover exoplanet that may offer a glimpse into earth's fate
description: Scientists have discovered an Earth-like planet orbiting a white dwarf star, providing insights into the future of our Solar System. The planet, about 1.9 times the mass of Earth, was likely pushed further out during the star's red giant phase. This discovery hints that Earth could survive the Sun’s red giant phase.

title: NASA finds a mysterious Zebra rock on Mars: Here's all about this new exciting discovery
description: NASA's Perseverance Rover has discovered a unique 'zebra rock' in Mars' Jezero Crater, characterized by black-and-white stripes. The rock, named 'Freya Castle,' is unlike any seen before on Mars and may have rolled downhill from a higher source. This discovery could lead to more exciting findings as the rover continues its mission.

title: One in two El Nino events could be extreme by 2050, study finds
description: A new study predicts that by 2050, one in every two El Nino events could be extreme if greenhouse gas emissions continue at current rates. This could lead to more frequent and intense weather events, impacting life and property. The study used computer models and fossil data to validate its findings.

title: Can X-rays, used for broken bones, be NASA's secret weapon to help save Earth from killer asteroids? Here's what scientists say
description: Scientists at Sandia National Laboratories have made significant strides in understanding how nuclear explosions could be employed to deflect dangerous asteroids. Through laboratory experiments simulating nuclear blasts using X-rays on a mock asteroid, the research demonstrates the viability of this approach. With recent advancements in planetary defense, such as NASA's DART mission, this study underscores the importance of preparedness against potential asteroid impacts in the future.

title: Though it's not the moon yet, it's the next best thing for European astronauts
description: The European Space Agency has opened the LUNA facility in Germany to simulate lunar conditions for astronaut training. The facility features ground-up volcanic rock and movable trolleys to mimic the moon's surface and low gravity. ESA aims to prepare astronauts for future moon missions under NASA's Artemis program by 2030.

title: Earth to encounter this fuzzy-star like comet after 80,000 years. Here's when and how to watch this rare cosmic event
description: Comet C/2023 A3, also known as Tsuchinshan-ATLAS, will be visible in the early morning hours from Friday through Monday. The comet, which last appeared 80,000 years ago, will look like a faint star with a hazy tail. It is expected to shine brightly by the end of September 2024.

title: SpaceX Crew Dragon mission: Obectives, launch date & time, and how to watch it live online
description: NASA is preparing for the SpaceX Crew-9 mission to the International Space Station, now set for September 28 due to Tropical Storm Helene. The mission will send three NASA astronauts and a Russian cosmonaut to the ISS and bring back two astronauts stranded due to issues with Boeing's Starliner spacecraft.

title: Indian-origin techie develops AI that not only captures every moment of your life but also tells you what to focus on
description: Advait Paliwal, an Indian-origin entrepreneur, has introduced Iris, an AI wearable device that captures life moments by taking pictures every minute. The device uses AI to organize and caption these images, helping users remember details. While it offers benefits for health and safety, privacy concerns have been raised.

title: 200-year-old message in a bottle left by archaeologist unearthed in France
description: Volunteers have discovered a 200-year-old message in a bottle at an excavation site in Normandy, France. The letter, left by archaeologist P.J Féret in 1825, provides details about the ancient Gaulish clifftop village near Eu. The discovery was unexpected and offers new insights into past excavations at the site.

title: Antarctica's ‘doomsday glacier’ nearing collapse, scientists warn it's happening sooner than expected
description: Scientists have discovered that Antarctica's Thwaites Glacier is melting rapidly and may be on an irreversible path to collapse, potentially causing catastrophic global sea level rise. Their six-year study revealed unexpected melting patterns and the significant impact of warm ocean water. Immediate action is required to mitigate these effects.

title: Untreatable fungal infections are now killing nearly 3.8 mn each year, WHO experts sound alarm
description: Deadly Fungal Infection: The world faces a growing crisis in antifungal resistance, with fungal infections causing millions of deaths annually. Researchers urge global health discussions to include this issue, as fungi are becoming resistant to current treatments. The upcoming UN meeting on antimicrobial resistance is seen as crucial for addressing this silent pandemic.

title: NASA’s Chandra X-ray observatory telescope identifies galaxy’s black hole delivery system, dubbed Nikhuli
description: NASA's Chandra X-ray Observatory and Hubble Space Telescope have identified a galaxy's black hole delivery system named 'Nikhuli,' after a term from the Sumi community in Nagaland. The study suggests that Nikhuli, a cluster of stars, is delivering a massive black hole to the spiral galaxy NGC 4424, located 54 million light-years from Earth.

title: Capsule carrying 2 Russians, 1 American returns to Earth from space station
description: A Soyuz capsule carrying two Russian astronauts, Oleg Kononenko and Nikolai Chub, and American astronaut Tracy Dyson successfully landed in Kazakhstan after undocking from the International Space Station.

title: Five Asteroids to Fear: NASA warns of space rocks with one packing firepower of nearly 5 mn Hiroshima bombs!
description: Asteroid Alert: NASA actively monitors asteroids that could potentially threaten Earth. The most concerning is Bennu, which has a 1 in 2,700 chance of impacting in 2182, potentially causing significant casualties. Other notable asteroids include 29075 (1950 DA) and 2023 TL4, with impact chances projected centuries away. Although all monitored asteroids are currently rated as zero risk, continuous vigilance is essential to ensure planetary safety.

title: Chandrayaan-3 discovers ancient 160-km crater on Moon, sheds new light on lunar history
description: India's Chandrayaan-3 mission has identified a 160-km-wide crater near its landing site on the Moon. The discovery, made by the Pragyan rover, provides crucial insights into the Moon's early geological evolution. This ancient crater, older than the Aitken basin, offers a rare opportunity to study one of the earliest lunar formations.

title: Scientists discover 120-million-year-old Earth section: Here's how it could change what we know about our planet
description: Geologists have uncovered a long-lost tectonic plate called Pontus, believed to have existed 120 million years ago in Borneo. Led by Suzanna van de Lagemaat from Utrecht University, the discovery reveals new information about Earth’s geological past and the breakup of Pangaea. This breakthrough, based on magnetic data from ancient rock formations, offers insights into how tectonic plates shaped modern-day regions like Borneo and the Philippines.

title: China startup's kerosene-powered rocket fails test flight
description: China's Deep Blue Aerospace announced that its reusable kerosene-fuelled rocket, Nebula-1, failed to complete a high-altitude vertical recovery test flight in Inner Mongolia. The rocket successfully completed 10 out of 11 tasks but crashed during the final stage due to a landing system failure, causing significant damage.

description: NASA plans to launch an artificial star by 2029 to help scientists calibrate telescopes and improve measurements of stellar brightness. This $19.5 million mission, led by George Mason University, aims to enhance our understanding of the universe's expansion and refine dark energy parameters, potentially leading to significant scientific breakthroughs.

One of them, Asteroid 2024 RO11, is notable for its size of 120 feet and will come within 4,580,000 miles of Earth. The smaller Asteroid 2020 GE, measuring 26 feet in diameter, will pass at a distance of approximately 410,000 miles.

He argues that in moments of heightened awareness, such as creativity or dreaming, consciousness may access these higher planes. While the theory has sparked interest, it faces skepticism within the scientific community regarding its implications and validity.

description: NASA has released an audio clip capturing sound waves from a supermassive black hole located 250 million light years away in the Perseus galaxy cluster. The waves were transposed up 57 and 58 octaves to make them audible to human ears, revealing eerie sounds that provide insights into intergalactic space.

title: Elon Musk calls for accountability, says 'FAA should fine Boeing, not SpaceX, for stranding astronauts in Space'
description: Elon Musk has criticised the FAA for fining SpaceX over licensing violations while ignoring safety issues at Boeing. The FAA fined SpaceX $633,009 for using an unauthorised launch control room and previously fined them for not submitting safety information. Musk argues that the FAA's actions jeopardise human lives and hinder innovation.

description: ISRO, IN-SPACe, and NSIL have signed five Technology Transfer Agreements with private companies, marking a total of 75 agreements since space reforms. This milestone aims to empower India's private sector to utilize advanced space technologies for commercial and societal applications. The agreements were signed with Anabond Ltd, Salvo Industries Pvt Ltd, Micropack Pvt Ltd, and Astra Microwave Products Ltd.

title: Study reveals role of gamma-delta T cells in cancer immunology
description: A study published in Cell Press reveals the significant role of gamma-delta T cells in treatment outcomes for 33 cancer types. Researchers at Moffitt Cancer Center found that these cells' diversity and clonality impact patient survival and treatment efficacy, providing new clinical biomarkers and therapeutic targets.

title: Eyes on moon: National space panel clears India’s 5th lunar mission Lupex; lander engine to be used to land humans on moon
description: India's lunar ambitions are advancing with the clearance of the fifth lunar mission, Lupex, to be jointly implemented by India and Japan. This mission, following Chandrayaan-1 to 4, aims to explore the Moon for water and resources, and marks a step towards India's goal of human lunar landing.

title: Scientists grow lost 'biblical tree' from 1,000-year-old seed
description: Archaeologists discovered a 1,000-year-old seed in the Judean desert, which grew into a 10-foot tree believed to be linked to biblical trees. Despite thriving, the tree did not produce aromatic compounds like myrrh. Research was published after confirming its distinct identity from Judean Balsam.

title: Weather may delay launch of mission to study deflected asteroid
description: Stormy weather might postpone the launch of Europe's Hera spacecraft, aimed at analyzing the aftermath of NASA's DART collision with the asteroid Dimorphos. Scheduled for Monday, the mission's objective is to gather crucial data on planetary defense. If postponed, a back-up launch is set for Tuesday. The launch window extends until October 27.

title: Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine: Who are Victor Ambros and Gary Ruvkun?
description: The 2024 Nobel Prize for Physiology or Medicine has been awarded to Victor Ambros and Gary Ruvkun for their discovery of microRNA and its role in post-transcriptional gene regulation. This groundbreaking work has revealed a new principle of gene regulation essential for multicellular organisms, including humans, with the human genome coding for over a thousand microRNAs.

title: Nobel Prize 2024 in Medicine goes to Victor Ambros and Gary Ruvkun for discovery of microRNA
description: Victor Ambros and Gary Ruvkun have been awarded the 2024 Nobel Prize for Physiology or Medicine for their discovery of microRNA and its role in post-transcriptional gene regulation. The prize follows the 2023 award to Katalin Karikó and Drew Weissman for groundbreaking mRNA vaccine research.

title: Asteroid may become new wonder-food for astronauts, claims new study
description: A study published in The International Journal of Astrobiology reveals a groundbreaking concept where astronauts could use asteroids to meet their nutritional needs. While the carbon from asteroids may be transformed into edible biomass, extensive testing is still required to ensure its safety. This new approach offers hope for addressing the challenge of food scarcity during long-duration space missions, though significant hurdles remain before it can be realized.

description: The European Space Agency's Hera spacecraft, launched by SpaceX, is embarking on a mission to examine the asteroid Dimorphos, which was impacted by NASA's Dart to test planetary defense. Hera will gather detailed scientific data to evaluate the effectiveness of the deflection and inform future strategies for protecting Earth.

title: NGLV development model will be announced soon: ISRO chief S Somnath
description: The ISRO chief announced that the model for the Next Generation Launch Vehicle (NGLV) will be revealed soon. This move will allow extensive industry participation from the design phase. The Union Cabinet has approved NGLV's development, aiming for operations at the Bharatiya Antariksh Station and an Indian crewed Moon landing by 2040.

title: What is daylight saving time after which US citizens get an extra hour of sleep? Explained
description: Daylight saving time, affecting North America, is under scrutiny due to recent legislative proposals and public sentiment. People will soon get an extra hour of sleep as clocks move back in November. The practice, which was first adopted by Germany in 1916, sees various debates including energy savings and potential health risks.

title: What is microRNA? All about Victor Ambros and Gary Ruvkun's discovery which won them Nobel Prize in Medicine 2024
description: Scientists Victor Ambros and Gary Ruvkun won the 2024 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for discovering microRNA and its role in gene regulation. This pivotal finding has clarified how organisms develop and function, with microRNAs playing a critical part in maintaining normal cellular functions and being linked to diseases such as cancer.

description: Primitive animals called comb jellies can fuse their bodies and nervous systems together.

description: Researchers predicting a 1,000-fold increase in such e-waste by 2030 have called for recycling strategies to reduce environmental impact.

description: She died as she lived—pursuing both particle physics and gender justice with equal passion at the Indian Institute of Science.

description: Health-tech firms are looking to use cutting-edge technologies to fill chronic, structural lacunae in the country’s healthcare delivery.

description: AI systems all function the same way, by identifying patterns. The truth is that machine learning systems struggle with difference.

description: Nobel Committee recognises 1980s work on neural networks and pattern recognition. Prize reaffirms AI’s growing impact on science and daily life.

title: Nasa plans to lay oxygen pipeline at Moon’s south pole for Artemis mission
description: NASA is developing the Lunar South Pole Oxygen Pipeline (L-SPoP) to revolutionize lunar exploration. This innovative pipeline will transport oxygen extracted from lunar resources to support human missions under the Artemis program. By utilizing in-situ materials and robotic construction, L-SPoP aims to reduce costs, risks, and reliance on Earth-based supplies, paving the way for a sustainable lunar presence.

title: JWT's latest discovery revealing red monster galaxies from the early universe
description: The James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) has discovered three massive galaxies, dubbed "red monsters," that challenge current theories of galaxy formation. These galaxies, formed just one billion years after the Big Bang, are far larger and more evolved than expected, suggesting that galaxies may have formed much faster in the early universe than previously thought.

title: Could octopuses take over Earth if humans go extinct?
description: Zoologist Professor Tim Coulson suggests that octopuses, with their remarkable intelligence and adaptability, could potentially become Earth's dominant species if humans were to disappear. Their advanced cognition and problem-solving skills hint at a future where they might develop complex societies, though their lack of physical adaptation for land poses a challenge.

title: 8 Fascinating outer space facts you need to know
description: Humanity's exploration of outer space continues to unveil astonishing discoveries that challenge our understanding of the cosmos. From the immense size of the universe, with more stars than grains of sand on Earth, to the bizarre phenomena like cold welding and the existence of a gigantic reservoir of water vapor, space remains a realm of endless wonder and mystery.

title: Future is fusion? The quest to build a star on Earth
Aircraft experiences 'near miss' with 'UFO': Pentagon report
description: The Pentagon's latest UFO report reveals 757 unexplained aerial phenomena sightings in the past year, including a near-collision between a commercial airliner and a cylindrical object off the coast of New York. While many sightings were later identified as ordinary objects, a significant number remain unexplained. Despite investigations, no evidence of extraterrestrial activity has been found.

title: Extreme weather could increase risk of groundwater contamination, study finds
description: A new study reveals that extreme weather events, fueled by climate change, are accelerating nitrate contamination of groundwater. Heavy rains following droughts can drive nitrates from fertilizers over 30 feet into the ground in mere days. This rapid percolation poses a significant threat to drinking water, particularly in regions heavily reliant on agricultural fertilizers.

title: Mysterious orbs and triangles: Pentagon's new report on UFO cases leave experts baffled
description: The Pentagon and intelligence officials released their yearly report on UFO sightings, now called UAPs. They investigated over 750 new reports but found no proof of alien life. However, 21 cases remain unexplained, often involving strange shapes like orbs and triangles seen near military areas. While some could be drones, experts are baffled and continue to investigate.

title: Scientists discover the largest coral colony on Earth in the Solomon Islands: Key insights on its size and age
description: A team of researchers from National Geographic's Pristine Seas team have discovered the world's largest coral colony in the Solomon Islands. The colony, which is larger than a blue whale and estimated to be centuries old, was found in October 2024 and is a testament to the resilience of marine life in the face of climate change.

title: African elephants face shocking 70% population decline due to habitat loss and poaching; study finds
description: A new study reveals alarming declines in African elephant populations, with savanna elephants down 70% and forest elephants down 90% since 1964. Poaching and habitat loss are the primary drivers, hitting northern and eastern Africa hardest. However, southern Africa offers hope, with conservation efforts leading to population increases in some areas.

title: Beaver moon 2024: Final supermoon of the year and a stunning celestial event for the skygazers!
description: November's night sky will be illuminated by the Beaver Moon, the final supermoon of 2024. This full moon, appearing larger and brighter than usual, peaks on November 15th. The name originates from beavers' active preparations for winter during this time. Alongside the supermoon, skywatchers can also observe the Pleiades star cluster.

title: Isro, IIT Madras partner to launch research centre for spacecraft thermal management
description: The Indian Institute of Technology Madras (IIT Madras) and the Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) have partnered to establish a new Centre of Excellence for Fluid and Thermal Sciences. With an initial investment of Rs 1.84 crore from ISRO, the Centre will focus on crucial research areas such as spacecraft thermal management and combustion instability in hybrid rockets.

title: Nasa’s Roman Space Telescope gets major upgrade in its quest to search space
description: Nasa has successfully integrated the Roman Coronagraph Instrument onto the Nancy Grace Roman Space Telescope. This milestone brings the mission one step closer to directly observing exoplanets by blocking the glare from their host stars.

title: Is AI dominance inevitable? A technology ethicist says no, actually
description: A growing chorus insists that artificial intelligence is inevitable and those who resist it risk being left behind. However, a closer look reveals a more nuanced reality. While AI holds promise in fields like medicine, its impact on productivity and education remains unclear, and its role in autonomous weapons raises serious ethical concerns.

title: AI agents more effective than GenAI for enterprise productivity: Deloitte Study
description: Deloitte's study reveals that AI agents surpass GenAI in business automation, handling complex tasks effectively. Unlike LLMs with limited task comprehension, AI agents leverage tools and memory for intricate processes, enhancing productivity and program delivery.

title: Scientists find another clue to uncover secrets of ageing
description: Scientists have mapped how aging happens across different organs in mice, finding common patterns of tissue damage and loss of cell identity. The study, published in Cell, used advanced imaging to create detailed maps of nine organs, revealing areas more prone to aging.

Following a process similar to absentee voting, Williams will submit her ballot electronically via NASA's secure communication network.

description: A virologist self-administered a treatment to help treat her own stage 3 cancer. Her actions sparked a debate around the ethics of self-experimentation. Researchers warned that it “should not be the first approach to dealing with diagnosed cancer”.

description: The objective of the study is to understand the science behind the infections, including the immunological basis for the susceptibility of different individuals.

description: This November, skywatchers can enjoy several celestial events, including the Taurid and Leonid meteor showers, the lunar occultation of Jupiter, and the full Beaver Moon. Uranus will also be at opposition, making it a prime month for astronomical observation.

title: Voyager-1’s cosmic comeback! NASA receives faint signal, thanks to 1981's backup transmitter
description: A command to activate a heater triggered its fault protection system, causing the communication issue. Voyager-1 has been operational for over 47 years in interstellar space.

description: Mount Fuji has not seen snow by October 30 for the first time in 130 years.&nbsp;

description: China successfully launched the Shenzou-19 spaceship carrying three astronauts to the Tiangong space station. The new team is likely to replace the team, which was staying at ISS for last six months.

description: Where on the Moon will Artemis III astronauts land? NASA said it is refining a list of nine areas near the lunar South Pole, “a place we’ve never set foot on before”.

description: Over 70% urban Indians claim to have improved their diets recently, while exercise is a regular activity for over 60%. But a significant share are okay with eating oily and fried foods or parathas, or even desserts frequently.

description: Will skinny still be desirable when it is more easily achieved by the masses?

description: The Central Drug Regulatory Authority flagged four drugs as spurious and identified 49 others as not meeting quality standards, including paracetamol and Oxytocin. Of 3,000 samples, only 1.5% were substandard, assuring public safety through ongoing inspections.

description: The ISS crew, consisting of four Americans and three Russians, returned to Earth after an eight-month mission. One NASA astronaut was hospitalised for precautionary reasons while the others were cleared. Their return was delayed due to technical issues and weather conditions.

title: SpaceX Dragon capsule to return NASA's Crew 8 astronauts to Earth after 6-month delay–where to watch live stream
description: NASA's Crew 8, consisting of three astronauts and one cosmonaut, commenced their return from the ISS via a SpaceX Dragon capsule.

description: LISA mission will be the “first gravitational wave detector in space” and will “explore the fundamental nature of gravity and black holes”. How will LISA detect ripples in spacetime? Why to study Gravitational Waves? Here's all you need to know.

description: The stomach influences every aspect of human health, says the philanthropist

title: NASA wears Prada: Spacesuit ‘capable of enabling human exploration of lunar south pole’ unveiled for Artemis III
description: The Artemis III mission will see NASA astronauts in Prada-designed spacesuits, showcased in Milan. Featuring advanced materials and unique designs, these suits aim to protect astronauts on lunar expeditions.

title: Sunita Williams' spacecraft set for redemption? NASA plans Starliner's next lift-off in 2025, but conditions apply
description: In August this year, NASA decided to return Boeing’s Starliner to Earth without humans aboard the spacecraft – keeping in view the safety of astronauts Sunita Williams and Butch Wilmore.

title: 5 stunning NASA images unveiling the wonders of stellar evolution
description: The dynamic cosmos evolves through the life and death of stars, creating elements for life. Supernova remnants are essential for solar system formation. Telescopes capture stunning imagery of star-forming regions, highlighting the role of massive stars in shaping our universe.

title: Can weight-loss drug help employment? This is how obesity drug Zepbound maker Eli Lilly can help UK
description: In a bid to combat obesity and unemployment, the UK govt is collaborating with Eli Lilly, which will invest £279 mn in a trial assessing weight loss jabs' effects on employment, productivity, and health-related quality of life over 5 years
