description: The challenge for neuroscientists is how to test them

title: Europa Clipper: NASA spacecraft lifts off for Jupiter's icy moon – WATCH
description: It will take Europa Clipper 5 1/2 years to reach Jupiter, where it will slip into orbit around the giant gas planet and sneak close to Europa during dozens of radiation-drenched flybys.

title: ‘Where can I buy ticket’: Anand Mahindra as Elon Musk's Starship rocket achieves historic manoeuvre | Watch
description: Elon Musk's Starship rocket on Sunday made history by successfully manoeuvring back to its launch tower. Anand Mahindra and many others reacted to this space travel milestone.

title: Indian stargazers capture rarest celestial view of ancient comet, last seen 80,000 years ago
description: An ancient comet—known as C/2023 A3 Tsuchinshan-ATLAS—discovered in 2023 when it approached the inner solar system on its highly elliptical orbit for the first time in documented human history—recently made its closest approach to Earth.

title: October full moon 2024 is Hunter's Moon. When and where will event be visible | All you need to know
description: Sky gazers are set to get a special treat this month on October 17. The celestial event of the full moon, which happens to be Hunter Moon this time, is likely to offer a rare spectacle, appearing closer than any other moon this year

title: Sahara Desert witnesses severe flooding after September rainfall; lake Iriqui filled with water first time in 50 years
description: Just two days of rainfall in September surpassed the yearly average of 250 mm including in most arid areas.

title: How to reduce the risk of developing dementia
description: A healthy lifestyle can prevent or delay almost half of cases

title: 5 NASA images explore mysteries of Nebulas, stellar evolution and cosmic wonders
description: NASA's exploration of nebulas, including unique structures like the 'eye' star and Westerlund 1, provides insights into star formation and stellar evolution. Hubble's observations reveal vibrant colors and complex patterns, enhancing our understanding of cosmic phenomena.

title: Did NASA’s experiment accidentally kill life on Mars?
description: An astrobiologist suggests that NASA's Viking missions in the 1970s may have inadvertently eliminated potential Martian life. The experiments, designed to detect life by introducing water, might have overwhelmed microbes adapted to Mars' hyperarid conditions. This theory challenges the traditional approach of seeking extraterrestrial life in water-rich environments and calls for new methods to detect life in extreme conditions.

title: Elon Musk teams up with India for a groundbreaking satellite launch – Find out more!
description: India will launch its largest communication satellite, Gsat-20, using SpaceX's Falcon-9 rocket. The satellite, weighing 4,700 kg, exceeds the capacity of India's current launch vehicle. SpaceX was chosen due to the unavailability of Arianespace and the ongoing conflict with Russia. Gsat-20 will enhance India's communication infrastructure, supporting initiatives like Smart City and in-flight internet connectivity.

title: 'There is something out there': Pentagon logs 757 UFO sightings in US, majority in airspace
description: The Pentagon's latest report on Unidentified Aerial Phenomena (UAPs) revealed hundreds of new sightings, mostly in airspace. While none pointed to extraterrestrial activity, many remain unexplained due to insufficient data. The report, compiled by the Pentagon's AARO, aims to address potential threats to national security and air safety.

title: Samples obtained by Chinese spacecraft show moon's ancient volcanism
description: China's Chang'e-6 mission brought back the first-ever samples from the moon's far side, revealing volcanic activity lasting at least 1.4 billion years. Analysis of the retrieved basalt fragments indicates eruptions occurred as far back as 4.2 billion years ago, offering new insights into the moon's early history and the evolution of volcanism on celestial bodies.

title: China may use Moon's soil to make bricks for lunar base
description: China is experimenting with lunar soil bricks to build a permanent base on the Moon by 2035. Prototype bricks, stronger than standard ones, will be tested in space for three years to assess their durability against harsh lunar conditions. Using lunar resources aims to reduce the cost of transporting materials from Earth.

title: 'Alien' message from Mars decoded by father-daughter duo contain movement, suggest life
description: The European Space Agency simulated contact from an extraterrestrial civilization, transmitting a message from its ExoMars Trace Gas Orbiter to Earth. Thousands of citizen scientists helped decode the complex signal, a visual message representing the building blocks of life. While deciphering the message took a year, interpreting its meaning remains an ongoing challenge open to public speculation.

title: ISRO's total investment to date is less than a single year's budget of NASA
description: Space Minister Jitendra Singh recently released a report which stated that for every dollar generated by the space sector, the Indian economy has seen a multiplier effect of $2.54. ISRO has budget which is about 15 times less than what US space agency NASA spends on space. The revenue of India's space sector has grown manifold in 2023 and it is the eight largest space economy in the world.

title: Scientist treats her own breast cancer with viruses she grew in the lab. All you need to know about the treatment
description: Beata Halassy, an expert infectious disease researcher, treated her own stage 3 breast cancer by injecting the tumour with lab-grown viruses. Following this treatment, 50-year-old Beata Halassy has been cancer-free for four years. This self-administered experimental vaccine called oncolytic virotherapy (OVT) helped her treat the stage 3 breast cancer.

title: For every rupee spent on ISRO, society got back Rs 2.50: ISRO chief Somanath
description: ISRO Chairman S Somanath revealed that a recent study by the agency indicated a return of Rs 2.50 for every rupee spent. He emphasized ISRO's commitment to serving India by fostering business opportunities in space technology for sustainable growth.

title: Zombie birds! Scientists turn deceased birds into high-tech drones
description: Researchers at New Mexico Tech are developing drones and robots using preserved bodies of dead birds. These "animatronic" birds aim to improve wildlife monitoring by blending in and minimizing disturbances. The team has created flapping-wing drones using pheasant and mallard parts, as well as a swimming duck robot. They've also developed stationary pigeons with cameras for surveillance purposes.

title: Uranus and its moons may have ideal conditions for life—but Voyager 2 missed it due to one bad day
description: New analysis of Voyager 2 data suggests that a solar storm may have skewed our understanding of Uranus and its moons.  Scientists now believe that the planet's magnetic field may be hiding vast oceans on its moons, Titania and Oberon, potentially capable of supporting life.  NASA's upcoming mission to Uranus aims to investigate this further.

title: Empire State building-sized 'God of Chaos' asteroid approaching Earth at 30,000 km per hour, NASA on high alert
description: The asteroid Apophis, nicknamed the "God of Chaos," is set for a near-Earth flyby on November 13, passing within 19,000 miles of our planet. While not posing an immediate threat, Apophis's size and proximity have drawn significant attention from NASA.  Scientists are using this opportunity to study the asteroid and develop potential defense strategies against future cosmic threats.

title: COP29: What is the latest science on climate change?
description: Scientists warn that the world may have already surpassed the critical 1.5°C warming threshold, pushing past a point of irreversible climate change.  Record-breaking temperatures are fueling more intense hurricanes, devastating wildfires, and widespread coral bleaching.  New research reveals alarming trends like the Amazon rainforest nearing a tipping point and a potential slowdown of the Atlantic Ocean current.

title: Worst hurricane to hit US since 2005 created waves 55 miles above ground: Watch NASA's shocking visual
description: Hurricane Helene, the deadliest hurricane since 2005, slammed into Florida's Gulf Coast, causing widespread destruction and claiming 227 lives across six states.  NASA's AWE instrument captured images of massive atmospheric gravity waves, confirming the hurricane's impact on the Earth's upper atmosphere.

title: IIT Guwahati researchers develop sustainable method for Ammonium removal from wastewater
description: Researchers at IIT Guwahati have developed an innovative method for removing ammonium from wastewater using microalgae and bacteria. This sustainable approach significantly reduces energy consumption compared to traditional methods by utilizing oxygen produced by microalgae during photosynthesis to convert ammonium into harmless nitrogen.

title: Suitcase-sized asteroid slips past NASA’s early warning system, strikes Earth hours after detection—third instance in 2024
description: A small asteroid, 2024 UQ, entered Earth's atmosphere and disintegrated last month. The asteroid was detected only two hours prior to impact. The incident marked the third time this year an asteroid, termed an "imminent impactor," was detected just hours before reaching Earth.

title: Ayurvedic vs Korean skincare: Find the best skincare for your needs
description: Ayurvedic vs Korean skincare: Find the best skincare for your needs

title: 2024 'virtually certain' to be hottest year on record: EU monitor
description: The EU climate monitor Copernicus says 2024 will be the hottest year on record. Global temperatures will likely be 1.5 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels. The UN climate negotiations will take place in Azerbaijan next week. Nations will set new carbon-cutting targets. The US experienced deadly flooding and hurricanes last month. Global warming causes intense downpours and storms.

title: Soon you can access Isro's navigational satellite signals using your mobile phone
description: India is making its navigation system, NaVIC, accessible to civilians via mobile phones by 2025.  The Indian Space Research Organisation (Isro) is also increasing satellite launches to meet growing demand and plans to focus on small launchers and satellites to capture the global market.  Additionally, India is working on a new space law to further support the burgeoning space sector.

title: Sunita Williams witnesses 16 sunrises, sunsets every day. Here's why
description: NASA astronaut Sunita Williams, currently on the International Space Station, experiences 16 sunsets and sunrises every day. For astronauts aboard the ISS sunrise and sunset isn't a once-a-day occurrence. It happens as many as 16 times. Sunita Williams has been stationed on the International Space Station since June 2023, faced delays in returning to Earth due to issues with Boeing’s Starliner.

title: Big industry needs to take plunge in space sector: ISRO chief Somanath
description: ISRO Chairman S Somanath urged major Indian industries to invest significantly in the space sector. He emphasized the need for building rockets and related systems to establish India as a space power by 2047. Somanath highlighted the lack of investment in the upstream segment and the importance of risk-sharing for the industry's growth.

title: India to launch ESA's Proba-3 spacecraft in December: Jitendra Singh
description: India is set to launch the European Space Agency's Proba-3 mission in early December from the Sriharikota spaceport. The mission, scheduled for December 4, will utilize ISRO's PSLV rocket to deploy two satellites into orbit. These satellites will study the Sun's corona, its outer atmosphere, by maintaining a precise formation to block the Sun's glare.

title: US-based Axiom Space explores using Indian rockets for space mission
description: US-based Axiom Space is considering Indian launch vehicles for its private space station project. The company is in talks with ISRO and Indian private space companies to potentially transport materials and diversify its supply chain. This follows a recent US-India space agreement and India's opening of its space sector to private companies, leading to increased funding for Indian space startups.

title: Money can buy happiness! Here's the science
description: New research challenges the age-old saying that money can't buy happiness. Economists and psychologists have found a strong correlation between wealth and well-being, suggesting that higher incomes contribute to both daily contentment and overall life satisfaction. Studies indicate this trend holds true even at the highest income levels, debunking the idea of a happiness plateau.

title: World's first wooden satellite, developed in Japan, heads to space
description: Japanese researchers have launched LignoSat, the world's first wooden satellite, into space. Constructed from honoki wood, LignoSat will orbit Earth for six months, testing the material's durability in extreme space conditions.

title: Moscow-Tehran ties in orbit: Russia launches record 55 satellites, including two from Iran
description: Russia launched a Soyuz rocket carrying two Ionosfera-M satellites to monitor Earth's ionosphere. The rocket also carried 53 smaller satellites, including two Iranian satellites, Kowsar and Hodhod. The Ionosfera-M satellites will join two others planned for launch in 2025, creating a four-satellite system for monitoring the ionosphere at an altitude of 510 miles.

title: China space station crew returns to Earth after 6 months in space
description: Three Chinese astronauts came back to Earth after spending six months on China's Tiangong space station. Their capsule landed in Inner Mongolia. The astronauts conducted experiments and spacewalks during their mission. China aims to become a leader in space exploration. The country has already brought back rocks from the moon and landed a rover on Mars.

title: What is Kodo millet or Varagu? How did a staple food turn deadly for 13 elephants in MP? How does the poison work?
description: Ten elephants died in Madhya Pradesh's Bandhavgarh Tiger Reserve due to suspected mycotoxins from kodo millet. The mycotoxins largely stem from fungal infections during harvesting in moist conditions. Previous cases have shown similar symptoms in humans and animals, but quick treatment can aid recovery.

title: Satellite mission discovers how 650-foot mega tsunami in 2023 left Earth shaking for 9 days
description: NASA and France's CNES detected the contours of a tsunami in a Greenland fjord in September 2023. It was triggered by a massive rockslide and created a global seismic signal lasting nine days. Experts warn that climate change could cause more such events as Arctic glaciers melt and destabilize surrounding mountain slopes.

title: 4,000-year-old ancient settlement discovered in Saudi Arabia’s Khaybar Oasis, sheds light on early urban life
description: Archaeologists have discovered a 4,000-year-old fortified town in northwest Saudi Arabia, revealing significant insights into the transition from nomadic to urban lifestyles. The town, named al-Natah, dates back to around 2400 BC and showcases early social complexity and urban planning. This discovery highlights the gradual shift towards urbanization in the Arabian Peninsula, with fortified oases playing a crucial role in fostering exchanges among pastoral nomads.

title: Raise the Space Bar: As SpaceX provides some of cheapest satellite launches, what can ISRO do to reclaim cost advantage?
description: SpaceX has revolutionised space travel by drastically reducing costs and demonstrating reusable rocket technology, leading to a boom in satellite launches. As SpaceX continues to innovate, ISRO must adapt and increase private sector involvement to remain competitive in the growing global launch services market.

title: Voyager 1 ‘phones home’ after 43 years using 1981 tech across 15 billion miles
description: NASA's Voyager 1 spacecraft reestablished communication with Earth on October 24 after a brief shutdown due to high power usage. The spacecraft switched to its seldom-used S-band transmitter, last activated in 1981. NASA engineers are investigating the cause of the fault protection system activation before reverting to the primary X-band transmitter. Voyager 1 continues to be a crucial asset in interstellar exploration since its launch in 1977.

title: 'Just as cosmos lights up universe, Diwali illuminates our homes and hearts': NASA shares special image to send greetings; Check here
description: NASA's Hubble Space Telescope has captured a stunning image of the Omega Nebula (M17), a significant star-forming region in the Milky Way galaxy. Located 5,500 light-years away in Sagittarius, this nebula hosts one of our galaxy’s youngest star clusters, obscured by gas and dust.

title: Isro launches analogue mission in Leh to train astronauts
description: The Indian Space Research Organisation (Isro) launches its first analogue space mission in Leh, Ladakh, to simulate extra-terrestrial conditions and study long-term human spaceflight challenges. This mission includes testing habitats and technologies, with collaborations involving multiple Indian institutions.

title: Meeting WHO's sodium recommendations could avert deaths from heart, kidney disease: Study
description: Reducing sodium intake according to WHO guidelines could prevent three lakh deaths from heart and kidney diseases in India over the next 10 years. The current national initiative, 'Eat Right India', promotes healthy eating but doesn't include mandatory sodium targets for packaged foods. Setting sodium benchmarks could save lives and significantly reduce healthcare costs.

title: Iconic black hole image in our milky way galaxy wrong? New research sheds light
description: Black hole image: The iconic image of black home in our milky way might not be accurate. A new research by a group of Japanese astronomers re-analyzed the images of the black hole Sgr A* published in 2022 and drew different conclusions. The new research has shed light on the iconic black hole image.

title: China launches new crew to its space station as it seeks to expand exploration
description: China successfully launched a three-person crew to its Tiangong space station, signaling further advancements in its space exploration program. The crew, comprising experienced astronaut Cai Xuzhe and newcomers Song Lingdong and Wang Haoze, aims to conduct spacewalks and install new station equipment. China's ambitions include moon missions and a research station on the lunar surface by 2030.

title: NASA's big breakthrough for Artemis III mission, when people will land on moon for the first time in over 5 decades
description: NASA Artemis III mission: Space agency NASA has made a significant step towards Artemis III mission, the first crewed Moon landing in over 50 years. NASA has identified an updated set of nine potential landing regions near the lunar South Pole for its Artemis III mission, it said in a release. These regions contain diverse geological characteristics and offer flexibility for mission availability, NASA said.

title: Sunita Williams stuck in space: Why NASA is not in a hurry to bring her back?
description: Sunita Williams stuck in space: NASA is not in a rush bring Sunita Williams and Butch Wilmore back to Earth. Boeing’s Starliner returned to Earth uncrewed on September 7 this year. Sunita Williams and Butch Wilmore will return in February via a SpaceX Crew Dragon spacecraft. But the question still arises- Why can't NASA send out a spacecraft and bring the astronauts back?

title: China says it's ready to launch the next crew to its orbiting space station early Wednesday
description: China is ready to launch a new crew to its Tiangong space station, with two men and one woman taking over from the current astronauts. The mission aims to conduct scientific experiments, perform space walks, and install protective equipment. This continues China's rapidly advancing space program, which includes plans for moon exploration.

title: "Greetings from the ISS": NASA astronaut Sunita Williams shares Diwali wishes from space
description: NASA astronaut Sunita Williams extended warm Diwali wishes from the International Space Station, sharing her unique experience of celebrating the festival from 260 miles above Earth. She expressed gratitude to President Biden and Vice President Harris for recognizing the community's contributions and reminisced about her father's efforts to keep their cultural roots alive.

title: ISRO to launch electric propelled satellite this December: Here’s why it’s a big deal for India
description: India plans to test its indigenously developed electric propulsion system for satellites by December. This technology will reduce satellite weight and fuel requirements. The test will feature Indian-made electric thrusters and travelling wave tube amplifiers. This will enhance satellite efficiency and functionality. ISRO is also progressing on the NASA-ISRO NISAR satellite launch scheduled for February.

title: Physical disabilities in senior citizens could have direct link to pollution: Study
description: A study in the US has found a link between long-term exposure to air pollutants and physical disabilities in elders, making daily activities difficult. It observed 15,411 participants over eight years, noting risks with pollutants like PM2.5, PM10, and NO2. Doctors recommended seniors limit pollution exposure using air purifiers and protective masks.

title: Is this AI tool accurate enough to predict your death? Here's what scientists say
description: AI Death Predictor:  Researchers have developed the AI-ECG Risk Estimator (AIRE), an AI mortality calculator that predicts health risks and lifespan based on ECG data. Set for trials in the UK next year, AIRE aims to enhance patient care by identifying serious heart conditions with high accuracy. However, experts warn that AI calculators should be used cautiously, as they cannot fully predict individual life expectancy due to various unpredictable factors.

title: India needs revolutionary growth to become developed economy: ISRO Chief S Somanathan
description: ISRO Chairman S. Somanathan emphasized the necessity of technological advancements and product development for India's transformation into a developed economy. He lauded Elon Musk's space innovations and highlighted India's progress, urging continuous efforts, private investment, and lifelong learning for future growth.

title: NASA Alerts: Asteroid five times the height of Taj Mahal set for close encounter, several more to follow!
description: NASA is set to monitor several asteroids, including 2024 TB2, 2007 UT3, and the larger 2020 WG, as they pass safely by Earth from October 26 to 28, 2024. While experts assure that these asteroids pose no threat, they offer valuable research opportunities to enhance our understanding of the solar system and improve planetary defense strategies.

title: NASA reports SpaceX Crew-8 astronaut in stable condition after emergency hospitalisation following return
description: NASA reported that one astronaut from the SpaceX Crew-8 mission was admitted to a hospital after their return from the International Space Station (ISS). The four crew members landed safely off the coast of Pensacola, Florida, early Friday morning after a record-setting 235 days in space. While initial assessments indicated that all crew members were healthy, a routine medical evaluation led to their transfer to a nearby medical facility for further examination.

title: Tracking 'Dana' approaching Odisha, West Bengal coasts: ISRO
description: ISRO's satellites EOS-06 and INSAT-3DR have been providing real-time data on Cyclonic Storm Dana approaching Odisha and West Bengal. Authorities have evacuated people, closed schools, canceled trains, and suspended flights in anticipation of the storm's landfall at a speed of 120 kmph.

title: Could a 3.2 billion-year-old meteorite the size of Everest have sparked life on Earth? Here's what we know
description: A study reveals that the S2 meteorite, estimated to be four times the size of Mount Everest, may have significantly influenced the emergence of life on Earth approximately 3.26 billion years ago. Despite its catastrophic impact, scientists propose that the ensuing tsunami and nutrient distribution could have created favorable conditions for early microbial life. Research teams recently collected samples from the meteorite’s impact site in South Africa to further investigate these theories.

title: This Chinese company launches ticket sales for space travel: Check prices and schedule
description: Deep Blue Aerospace will begin selling two tickets for a 2027 commercial spaceflight. The tickets cost 1.5 million yuan each. Passengers will experience five minutes of zero gravity. Tickets will be sold during a livestream by the company's founder. A deposit of 50,000 yuan is required to secure a ticket.

title: Barnard’s Star Finally Has a Planet, and Possibly More
description: For a century, exoplanet hunters have “discovered” planets around a nearby star, only to retract the claims. But the latest find is for real.

title: Can These Ex-Hollywood Chimps Find a Place Among the Apes?
description: Behind the scenes at a Chicago zoo, chimpanzees who spent years entertaining humans are learning to befriend their own kind.

title: Leonids Meteor Shower: When and How to Watch Its Peak
description: The event produces some of the year’s fastest meteors, although the nearly full moon may make them challenging to spot.

title: NASA Says Astronaut Suni Williams Is in ‘Incredible Health’
description: The agency’s top medical official was responding to rumors that Suni Williams had lost an unusual amount of weight during an extended stay in orbit.

title: Americans Have Regained Modest Trust in Scientists, Survey Finds
description: A sharp partisan divide remains over how involved researchers should be in policy decisions.

title: Pythons Have Surprising Social Lives
description: Ball pythons were long assumed to be solitary, but scientists discovered the snakes in captivity prefer each others’ company when given the chance to live socially.

title: ‘Devious’ New Deep Sea Slug Hid Its Identity From Scientists
description: It took nearly 25 years for biologists to discover that a swimming and glowing organism in the ocean’s midnight zone was actually a sea slug.

title: This ‘Ghost’ Fish Seemed Extinct, Until It Turned Up in Unexpected Places
description: No one saw a Mekong giant salmon carp for 15 years, but then the species was spotted in areas of Cambodia that suggest it may be found in more locations.

title: Uranus Might Have Experienced a Freak Event When Voyager 2 Visited
description: Much of the understanding of the seventh planet comes from a brief flyby nearly 40 years ago, which researchers now say overlapped with an exceptional solar event.

title: ChatGPT Defeated Doctors at Diagnosing Illness
description: A small study found ChatGPT outdid human physicians when assessing medical case histories, even when those doctors were using a chatbot.

title: First U.S. Case of Spreading New Mpox Type Reported in California
description: The unidentified patient had recently returned from Africa, where the virus has caused a deadly epidemic, health officials said.

title: Thomas E. Kurtz, co-creator of BASIC programming language, dies at 96
description: At Dartmouth, long before the days of laptops and smartphones, he worked to give more students access to computers. That work helped propel generations into a new world.

title: Democrats’ Message at COP29 Climate Talks: Don’t Panic
description: American officials are seeking to assure the world that U.S. climate action won’t end with the return of Donald Trump as president.

title: Why Kennedy Sees an ‘Epidemic’ of Chronic Disease Among Children
description: Trends in child health are in fact worrisome, and scientists welcome a renewed focus on foods and environmental toxins. But vaccines and fluoride are not the cause.

title: RFK Jr.'s Vow to Take On Big Food Could Face Resistance
description: Processed foods are in the cross hairs of Robert F. Kennedy Jr., but battling major companies could collide with President-elect Donald J. Trump’s corporate-friendly goals.

title: Nuclear Power Was Once Shunned at Climate Talks. Now, It’s a Rising Star.
description: Growing worldwide energy demand and other factors have shifted the calculus, but hurdles still lie ahead.

title: The Anti-Fluoride Movement Vaults Into the Mainstream
description: With the nomination of Robert F. Kennedy Jr. as health secretary, a formerly fringe opinion suddenly gets wide attention.

title: Chemist Identifies Mystery ‘Blobs’ Washing Up in Newfoundland
description: A researcher thinks he knows what has been coming ashore on miles of beaches. Canada’s environmental agency says it is still looking into it.

title: Canadian Teenager Is Country’s First Human Bird Flu Case
description: A teenager in British Columbia was hospitalized in critical condition with the disease, and officials were working to find out how the person was exposed to the virus.

title: COP29 Climate Talks Focus on Financing
description: Negotiators agree that trillions are needed to help lower-income countries adapt and cope, but not on who should pay.

title: Venom Helped Create Weight-Loss Drugs. What Else Could It Do For Us?
description: A study of Gila monster venom helped start the revolution in weight-loss drugs. But scientists think that’s just the beginning.

title: A.D.H.D. Symptoms Are Milder With a Busy Schedule, Study Finds
description: New research suggests symptoms of the disorder may be less severe in those with a demanding schedule.

title: 2024 Fossil Fuel Emissions Are Headed for a Record
description: Countries promised to move away from coal, oil and natural gas at last year’s climate summit. New research shows they’re burning more than ever before.

title: US Regulators Seek to Block UnitedHealth’s $3.3 Billion Purchase of Home Care Company
description: The Justice Department and four Democratic state attorneys general argued that United’s takeover would limit competition and harm consumers needing home or hospice care.

title: At COP29, Keir Starmer Announces the UK’s Ambitious Climate Targets
description: The prime minister announced more ambitious climate targets, charting a very different course from the United States, which is expected to roll back its energy transition plans.

title: At Long Last, the Surge in S.T.I.s May Be Leveling Off
description: Rates of gonorrhea declined in 2023, while diagnoses of syphilis and chlamydia held roughly steady, according to new C.D.C. data.

title: Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s FDA Wish List: Raw Milk, Stem Cells, Heavy Metals
description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., one of President-elect Donald J. Trump’s advisers on health, is taking aim at the agency’s oversight on many fronts.

title: Biden Officials Try to Reassure COP29 Climate Talks
description: Negotiators at the summit in Azerbaijan fear that the return of Donald Trump will sap momentum for global climate action.

title: As the Pandemic Deepened, Americans Kept Drinking More
description: Excessive drinking persisted in the years after Covid arrived, according to new data.

title: 'The sixth great extinction is happening', conservation expert warns
description: Conservationist Jane Goodall on the urgent need to turn the tide on climate change and nature loss.

title: Volcanoes once erupted on the far side of the moon
description: Volcanic rock, dating back billions of years, has been detected in the first samples collected from the mysterious "dark side".

title: COP29 hosts accused of detaining climate defenders
description: Human rights groups have called for a review of how countries are chosen to host the COP climate summits.

title: Runaway 'spy whale' fled Russian military training says marine scientist
description: Marine scientist uncovers the story behind Andruha's escape from Russian military training programme.

title: UN climate talks 'no longer fit for purpose' say key experts
description: Call for change comes after host country Azerbaijan's president calls oil and gas a "gift of God".

title: New study on moons of Uranus raises chance of life
description: The planet Uranus and its five biggest moons may not be the sterile worlds scientists have long thought.

title: Somebody moved UK's oldest satellite, and no-one knows who or why
description: Britain's oldest satellite is in the wrong part of the sky, but no-one's really sure who moved it.

title: This year set to be first to breach 1.5C global warming limit
description: It is also set to be the world's first breach of 1.5C of warming across an entire calendar year.

title: Politicians not ambitious enough to save nature, say scientists
description: Representatives of 196 countries have been meeting in Cali, Colombia, as part of the COP biodiversity summit.

title: Deadliest weather made worse by climate change - scientists
description: Human-caused climate change made recent extreme weather events more intense and more likely, new analysis finds.

title: Alarm call as world's trees slide towards extinction
description: Scientists have revealed that more than a third of tree species are facing extinction.

title: World way off target in tackling climate change - UN
description: The world is wildly off track in tackling climate change, the UN says, as CO2 in the atmosphere accumulates faster than ever

title: Polar bears face higher risk of disease in a warming Arctic
description: Climate change and sea ice loss leaves polar bears exposed to more diseases, research suggests.

title: Nature presenter Chris Packham settles case over axing of green policy
description: The TV presenter says the previous Tory administration was "reckless" to scale back climate policy.

title: Mega meteorite tore up seabed and boiled Earth's oceans
description: It was 200 times bigger than the one that wiped out the dinosaurs nearly three billion years later.

title: What is biodiversity and how can we protect it?
description: Colombia is hosting talks to assess global progress in protecting 30% of all land and water by 2030.

title: Burning rubbish now UK’s dirtiest form of power
description: Nearly half of waste is now burned for energy, but BBC analysis finds it is as dirty as coal.

title: How unusual has this hurricane season been?
description: Hurricanes Helene and Milton have bookended a particularly stormy period. What's behind it?

title: What's next for Elon Musk's SpaceX Starship rocket?
description: The world's most powerful rocket is expected to be back in action again soon
